articles.headline: Searching for Yield, at Almost Any Price
articles.snippet: Investors are desperate for better returns on their investments, but are largely having to settle for lesser quality these days.
articles.abstract: Investors are desperate for better returns on their investments, but are largely having to settle for lesser quality these days.
articles.lead_paragraph: When buyers demand something, the supply will be created.

articles.headline: Call for Limits on Web Data of Customers
articles.snippet: The long-awaited administration report suggests that tech companies disclose the information they collect on customers.
articles.abstract: The long-awaited administration report suggests that tech companies disclose the information they collect on customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House, hoping to move the national debate over privacy beyond the National Security Agency’s surveillance activities to the practices of companies like Google and Facebook, released a long-anticipated report on Thursday that recommends developing government limits on how private companies make use of the torrent of information they gather from their customers online.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Donors Weigh Jilting Christie for Jeb Bush
articles.snippet: Some donors and fund-raisers are signaling to Chris Christie’s camp that, should Jeb Bush enter the race for president, their first loyalty would be to him, not to Mr. Christie.
articles.abstract: Some donors and fund-raisers are signaling to Chris Christie’s camp that, should Jeb Bush enter the race for president, their first loyalty would be to him, not to Mr. Christie.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush’s increasingly serious and public examination of a run for president has shaken the ranks of establishment Republican donors and fund-raisers who had planned to back Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey in 2016, forcing many of them to rethink their allegiance to the embattled governor.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Timeline Describes Frantic Scene at Oklahoma Execution
articles.snippet: Clayton Lockett was shocked with a Taser, slashed his own arm and had a catheter inserted in the hours leading up to a botched execution attempt, according to a detailed timeline.
articles.abstract: Clayton Lockett was shocked with a Taser, slashed his own arm and had a catheter inserted in the hours leading up to a botched execution attempt, according to a detailed timeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALESTER, Okla. — Early on the morning of Clayton D. Lockett’s scheduled execution, he defied prison officers seeking to shackle him for the required walk to get X-rays. So they shocked him with a Taser, Oklahoma’s chief of corrections stated in an account released Thursday of Mr. Lockett’s final day, before his execution went awry.
articles.byline: By Erik Eckholm and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Spending and Pay Gains Suggest Better Economy
articles.snippet: The better-than-expected numbers for employment and spending improved the short-term outlook for renewed growth.
articles.abstract: The better-than-expected numbers for employment and spending improved the short-term outlook for renewed growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a winter that seemed endless, has the long-awaited spring economic thaw arrived?

articles.headline: Hoping to Fend Off Suits, G.M. Is to Return to Bankruptcy Court
articles.snippet: The automaker is trying to fend off a rising tide of class-action lawsuits stemming from its recall of 2.6 million cars because of a dangerously defective ignition switch that it now links to 13 deaths.
articles.abstract: The automaker is trying to fend off a rising tide of class-action lawsuits stemming from its recall of 2.6 million cars because of a dangerously defective ignition switch that it now links to 13 deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: An unusual meeting took place this week at a law office high in a Times Square skyscraper. Lawyers from about 100 law firms participated, either in person or by phone. The agenda: solidifying a strategy for taking on General Motors in bankruptcy court.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: U.S. Looks Into Wagers, Pro and Con, on Herbalife
articles.snippet: Federal agencies have trained their focus on traders who bet both on the diet supplements company and against it.
articles.abstract: Federal agencies have trained their focus on traders who bet both on the diet supplements company and against it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three federal agencies and one billionaire hedge fund manager have placed Herbalife under the microscope, scrutinizing whether the diet-supplements company is a pyramid scheme.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: As Netflix Resists, Most Firms Just Try to Befriend Comcast
articles.snippet: Most companies have not publicly spoken out against the proposed Comcast merger, partly to avoid antagonizing a company with which they do business.
articles.abstract: Most companies have not publicly spoken out against the proposed Comcast merger, partly to avoid antagonizing a company with which they do business.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the middle of an otherwise routine earnings report last week, Netflix took an unexpected detour into the realm of antitrust enforcement: It opposed Comcast’s proposed purchase of Time Warner Cable, it said, because the deal would create a powerful giant with “anticompetitive leverage.”

articles.headline: A Heinous Crime, Secret Histories and a Sinn Fein Leader’s Arrest
articles.snippet: The arrest of Gerry Adams on Wednesday came after officials subpoenaed interviews from a Boston College oral history project whose subjects had been promised confidentiality.
articles.abstract: The arrest of Gerry Adams on Wednesday came after officials subpoenaed interviews from a Boston College oral history project whose subjects had been promised confidentiality.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For years, the researchers painstakingly recorded and transcribed oral histories from many of the leaders of the factions caught up in the Troubles in Northern Ireland. They pledged absolute secrecy to their subjects until after their deaths.

articles.headline: Jump in Payrolls Is Seen as a Sign of New Optimism
articles.snippet: After a slowdown at the start of the year, the American economy picked up in April in tandem with the warming weather, expanding payrolls by 288,000, as the jobless rate fell to 6.3 percent.
articles.abstract: After a slowdown at the start of the year, the American economy picked up in April in tandem with the warming weather, expanding payrolls by 288,000, as the jobless rate fell to 6.3 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a frustrating series of false starts since the economic recovery began five years ago, American businesses appear to be increasingly confident about hiring new workers.

articles.headline: Steve Jobs Defied Convention, and Perhaps the Law
articles.snippet: Mr. Jobs’s conduct is a reminder that the difference between genius and potentially criminal behavior can be a fine line.
articles.abstract: Mr. Jobs’s conduct is a reminder that the difference between genius and potentially criminal behavior can be a fine line.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Steve Jobs were alive today, should he be in jail?

articles.headline: Bodice-Ripper in New Hands
articles.snippet: Harlequin, owned by the Canadian media company Torstar Corporation, is among the world’s largest publishers of romance novels, consistently one of America’s most popular genres.
articles.abstract: Harlequin, owned by the Canadian media company Torstar Corporation, is among the world’s largest publishers of romance novels, consistently one of America’s most popular genres.
articles.lead_paragraph: When News Corporation announced on Friday that it was buying the romance-novel publisher Harlequin Enterprises, cheap jokes inevitably started to fly.

articles.headline: 43 Questions to Ask Before Picking a New Town
articles.snippet: Rather than using a standard checklist of what to ask when looking for a place to live, a values audit could yield more happiness for less money.
articles.abstract: Rather than using a standard checklist of what to ask when looking for a place to live, a values audit could yield more happiness for less money.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes time to move to the suburbs, pick a town or settle in a new neighborhood, the checklist generally begins like this: Best school test scores. Most house for the money. Shortest commute.
